name: 4-(4-morpholinylmethyl)benzoic acid
Reason: 4-Morpholinylmethyl is a functional group that can significantly impact the melting point. Morpholine itself has a melting point around 100°C due to its rigid structure and hydrogen bonding potential. The methyl group can also contribute to the melting point, albeit at a lower extent. The basic unit for our comparison will be benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of four additional phenyl rings. Phenyl groups, when connected to a benzene ring, tend to increase the melting point due to the enhancement of the crystalline structure and the increase in molecular weight. In the case of 4-(4-morpholinylmethyl)benzoic acid, we have four additional phenyl rings linked in a linear fashion, which would notably augment the melting point. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight. Additionally, the morpholinylmethyl group introduces a rigid structure with potential hydrogen bonding, estimated at around +20°C. The methyl group can also contribute to the melting point, albeit at a lower extent.
